results.title: What I have written
results.creator_credit: John Hughes, Peter Sainsbury, Early Works and Beyond Films
results.brief_description:
Australian marital drama, which explores notions of identity and fidelity. Sorel and Christopher’s marriage is in the process of recovering from an extended period of alienation, when Christopher, a writer and poet, suffers an apparently fatal stroke. Shortly afterwards Sorel receives a manuscript written by her husband, of which she knows nothing. To her chagrin it reads as a thinly veiled account of their disintegrating marriage and a recent affair of her husband’s conducted whilst they were holidaying in Paris. Sorel reads Christopher’s novella and discovers his secret erotic yearnings for others and disgust for her. But is it true? Sorel can only hopelessly rage at her comatose husband whilst attempting to unravel their past. Assuming a sophisticated style, the film utilises stills, black and white photography, and a shifting voiceover to convey a multi-layered narrative. But despite its stylish aesthetic, an over reliance on such devices, which attempts to instil the mise-en-scene with a sense of mystery and eroticism, stagnates the narrative and exacerbates the

Credits: Producer, Peter Sainsbury, John Hughes ; director, John Hughes ; writer, John A. Scott ; photography, Dion Beebee ; music, David Bridie, John Phillips, Helen Mountford ; editing, Uri Mizrahi.
Cast: Angie Milliken, Jacek Koman, Fiona Stewart, Gillian Jones, Martin Jacobs.

results.title: Australians at war: 1939-1945: navy, army, airforce
results.creator_credit: Stuart Glover, John Morris, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
During the years 1956-1969 Frank Bagnall produced a series tracing the involvement of the Army, Navy and Airforce services during the Second World War. The series is comprised almost entirely of actual footage and is united by the themes of human effort and sacrifice. The individual episodes are available separately in the collection on 16mm. NAVY: illustrates the conditions of active service in the Royal Australian Navy in the war including missions such as an Island invasion with America, and defending bases in New Guinea and Northern Australia. ARMY: records the Australian soldier’s participation in the Second World War. Covers fighting in Libya, Greece, Crete, Syria and Tripoli, and the Singapore, New Guinea and Borneo campaigns. AIRFORCE: Australian airmen serve their country admirably, earning distinction in areas as widely separated as New Guinea and Europe. Victory comes at a cost however as machines and men are lost in the name of conflict. Repackaged by Film Australia in 1995.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_moP0lr2s1w
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xSlHLFAQlGg&t=13s
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3A6szu1ca0Y&t=25s

results.title: #TeenageDirtbag challenge
results.material_description: digital screen recording of @parishilton's TikTok post
results.brief_description: Over 20 years since Wheatus released their song ‘Teenage Dirtbag’ its nostalgic allure is still as potent as ever. The “Teenage dirtbag” challenge has been popularized by users and celebrities alike, including Paris Hilton, Christina Aguilera and Tara Reid. Compiling photos from adolescence in the early 2000’ to the Wheatus song. Think emo, myspace, American Pie and of course Paris Hilton. Like most viral trends there has been a divide between younger gen z and the millennials who were actually around for the period, dubbed “Indie Sleeze”
results.description: Over 20 years since Wheatus released ‘Teenage Dirtbag’, its nostalgic allure remains as potent as ever. The “Teenage Dirtbag” challenge, which sees people compile photos of their early 2000s adolescence to the song, has been popularised by everyday users and celebrities alike, including Paris Hilton, Christina Aguilera and Tara Reid. Think emo, MySpace, American Pie and, of course, Paris Hilton. Like most viral trends there’s been a divide between younger Gen Z and the Millennials who were actually around for the “Indie Sleeze” period.

Like most viral trends there has been a divide between younger Gen Z and the Millennials who were actually around for the period dubbed “Indie Sleeze”.

results.title: In the beginning
results.brief_description: A colourful clay animation film which satirizes society and its impulse to invent nuclear weapons which cause self-destruction. Looks at the invention of destructive weapons from raspberries to rockets! Narration: Brian Woods. Animation: Mark D’Arcy-Irvine, Masfufah Sani. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: Screen Worlds opening : September 2009
results.brief_description:
On Thursday September 17, 2009 ACMI’s new permanent screen culture exhibition Screen Worlds, was officially launched. The red carpet, VIP event attracted world wide attention with the attendance of both internationally recognised and home grown guests and artists. Kicking off the formalities was ACMI’s Board President, John Thwaites, followed by ACMI Director Tony Sweeney, Oscar® Winning Actress Cate Blanchett, Victorian Arts Minister Lynne Kosky and Victorian Premier John Brumby.
Following this, the ribbon is cut and guests enter the exhibition for the first time.

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film is shot in New Guinea and features the filmmaker’s family and friends, locals, people gathering in vast numbers for celebrations in various traditional dress, Chinese dragon display, scenic views, and road safety issues. Most likely filmed around Goroka, as the filmmaker lived mainly in Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:00:00 opens with footage shot around the filmmaker’s home; we see a sign with his name, Alex Sinclair, out the front of the white house; family and friends around the garden
00:03:23:00 car wreck being towed away and off the road
00:04:50:00 filmmaker and friends have a picnic on top of a hill. Local kids come to watch and pose for the camera.
00:05:55:00 along a river, feeding fish with friends, and a nearby wild bird sanctuary or zoo
00:07:29:00 Missionary Aviation Fellowship aircraft at airfield
00:08:32:00 stunning mountain views
00:10:14:00 lunch with friends at a restaurant near the bay
00:11:24:00 traditional Chinese Dragon dance and fire crackers along a town street
00:12:35:00 Lions Club road safety campaign displaying cars salvaged from crashes
00:13:46:00 celebrations of people in traditional dress from various districts; remarkable head dresses and masks made from mud or clay, alongside those made from feathers and woven materials, dancing, building hut demonstrations
00:14:36:00 more truck accidents; local kids come to see, then dance and entertain the filmmaker and friends
00:15:46:00 more stunning views of mountains
00:16:14:00 more ceremonial gatherings of various people and audiences

results.title: Whereas the people
results.brief_description: Traces the development of the Australian Constitution and investigates its relevance for today as well as examining the politics behind its drafting. The continuous “battle” between State and Federal powers is illustrated by the Franklin Dam case and the process of Constitutional change through referendum is explained.

holdings.name: VHS; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 84]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

This film shows the ‘J. Gadsden Pty. Ltd.’ factory in North Coburg (now a heritage listed location) from early construction through to completion and operational. We see the production line during the manufacture of Coralite British Kerosene packaging and other unidentified products.

results.title: Operation and care of the RCA 400 16mm sound projector
results.creator_credit: Crawley Films and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: Explains by use of close-up photography the threading, operation and care of the RCA 400 16 millimetre film and sound projector. Demonstrates the correct procedures for setting up and operating the equipment. Illustrates the packing up, cleaning and lubricating of the projector.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 166]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This is a particularly lovely colour film comprising scenes from Ron and Jess Gadsden’s early life when their children were small, in 1952. They are enjoying life at home (Lansell Rd, Toorak in Melbourne), sitting in the sun with the children, on the beach at Frankston on the Mornington Peninsula and a birthday for one of the girls back at Lansell Rd.

The second half of the film shows school sports at the Geelong Grammar Toorak Campus, ‘Glamorgan’, which Ron films through a round frame.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:59:00 Jess Gadsden teaches one of her children to swim in shallows at Frankston beach
00:01:59:00 view of Frankston bay with cliff top houses in the background
00:02:20:00 filmmaker Ron playing in water with his children
00:03:12:00 Jess preparing lunch on a small plate sitting on the beach
00:04:14:00 birthday party at Jess and Ron Gadsden’s home, with family and pony rides
00:06:42:00 sports day for primary school children with onlooking parents and teachers guiding the proceedings
results.description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This is a particularly lovely colour film comprising scenes from Ron and Jess Gadsden’s early life when their children were small, in 1952. They are enjoying life at home (Lansell Rd, Toorak in Melbourne), sitting in the sun with the children, on the beach at Frankston on the Mornington Peninsula and a birthday for one of the girls back at Lansell Rd.

The second half of the film shows school sports at the Geelong Grammar Toorak Campus, ‘Glamorgan’, which Ron films through a round frame.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:59:00 Jess Gadsden teaches one of her children to swim in shallows at Frankston beach
00:01:59:00 view of Frankston bay with cliff top houses in the background
00:02:20:00 filmmaker Ron playing in water with his children
00:03:12:00 Jess preparing lunch on a small plate sitting on the beach
00:04:14:00 birthday party at Jess and Ron Gadsden’s home, with family and pony rides
00:06:42:00 sports day for primary school children with onlooking parents and teachers guiding the proceedings
